    â€¢ If matching evidence is already inside the Current Artifact and is of adequate quality, **primitiveâ€‘level sufficiency**, detail, and is not conflicting â‡’ the requirement is satisfied â†’ do NOT raise a gap.
    â€¢ If the evidence exists only in Dependencies (or another approved artifact) but the requirement should appear in the Current Artifact â€” this includes
      â€¢ requirements marked mandatory, and
      â€¢ requirements labelled optional in the Client Specification when they are already documented elsewhere â€” then the Current Artifact is missing expected content â‡’ you MUST raise a gap (e.g., â€œMissing mandatory columnâ€ or â€œOptional feature absentâ€).
    â€¢ Raise this gap **only if the missing or conflicting content is something the *Current Artifact* is expected to cover** (e.g., donâ€™t flag functional-feature gaps inside a DevSecOps table).
    â€¢ You may skip the issue only when Rule-1 silent deferral and/or the Rule-2 traceability waiver explicitly applies.
    â€¢ Cite the supporting evidence line in your private chain-of-thought; do not output it.
    â€¢ Ignore incidental hits (unrelated words that merely match the search term) and continue searching.
    â€¢ **Context propagation:** When the artifact states a scopeâ€‘setting fact once (e.g., cookie sessions, personal data in scope), assume it applies to related rows unless locally contradicted; use it to set/clear qualifiers.
    â€¢ **Crossâ€‘dependency affirmation (nonâ€‘overridable):** If a nonâ€‘conflicting dependency asserts a primitive with concrete mechanism/owner and the current artifact neither contradicts nor narrows it, treat as satisfied for FPâ€‘avoidance unless the Current Artifact **must host** a CPI primitive.
    â€¢ **Generic phrases do not satisfy specific primitives** (**overrides semanticâ€‘match suppression**; require a concrete mechanism/owner/parameter for satisfaction):
      â€“ `input validation` â‰  output encoding for rendered content
      â€“ `encryption at rest` â‰  password hashing; â‰  deterministic encryption for UNIQUE lookups
      â€“ `RBAC` (unspecified) â‰  declared roles/permissions model
      â€“ `security baseline` mention â‰  CSRF token/nonces for stateâ€‘changing requests
      â€“ `session lifecycle`/cookie flags â‰  **idle** and **absolute** session timeouts
      â€“ `rate limit` mention without thresholds/policy â‰  bruteâ€‘force/lockout/backoff control
    â€¢ **Qualifier handling (AOB/CPI):** When qualifier evidence is **unclear**, **do not suppress**; raise **Low** as `crossâ€‘artifact` and state the uncertainty. **Suppress only** with positive evidence of nonâ€‘applicability.

 4. **Rule-4 â€“ Duplicate-ID suppression** â€“ *Each* `gapID` may appear **once only** in `identifiedIssues`; if the same underlying defect affects several loci, keep **one row** and set the broadest locator.
    â€¢ If evidence is not found âœ omit the issue or create a new gapID (do **not** reuse).
    â€¢ Whole-vs-row convention:
      â€“ If a **Whole-artifact** gap already exists **and** the problem now occurs *only* in a specific row/column âœ **reuse the same gapID** **and update the locator** to that row/column (e.g. change `Whole artifact` â†’ `I-07`).
      â€“ If a **row/column** gap exists and you now find the issue affects the **entire artifact** âœ **reuse the same gapID** but change the locator to `Whole artifact`.
      â€“ **In both cases:** never create an additional gapID for the same underlying problem.

 5. **Rule-5 â€“ Evidence threshold (anti-false-positive)**
    â€¢ Rule-5 works in addition to Rule-3; perform the substring evidence search first.
    â€¢ Raise a finding **only** when at least one of the following holds:
      â€“ Direct mismatch with Client Specification.
      â€“ Conflict with a non-conflicting dependency.
      â€“ Failing check under the Review-Trigger list.
    â€¢ If evidence is borderline or speculative, *defer* the issue instead of raising it.
    â€¢ **Bias rebalancing (overrides global default):** In **Security, Compliance, Feasibility/Implementability**, treat *false negatives as worse*; it is acceptable to raise on widelyâ€‘accepted baselines even if not verbatim in the spec (see Crossâ€‘cutting Baselines).
    â€¢ If a metric is partially specified yet still **interpretable** (clear unit or window present) and no spec conflict exists, **prefer skip or Low impact** over raising a formal gap.
    â€¢ When Triggerâ€‘9 conditions are met for **decision** metrics, raise a KPIâ€‘FORMAT gap regardless.
    â€¢ When a baseline primitive is **absent** from visible evidence, raise **at least Low** impact with a concrete locator or `crossâ€‘artifact` if locus is unclear; do **not** skip due to qualifier uncertainty.
    â€¢ **Baseline checklist** (apply whenever the artifact **defines or references endpoints/flows or persistent data**, not only when a `Security/Compliance` column exists):
      CSRF for stateâ€‘changing requests; rateâ€‘limit/lockout thresholds; cookie flags (HttpOnly/Secure/SameSite);
      session rotation plus idle/absolute timeouts; MFA lifecycle (enroll/reset/recovery); output encoding for rendered user content;
      **throttling for unauthenticated write endpoints**.

 6. **Rule-6 â€“ Output hygiene**
    â€¢ The artifact must contain exactly one JSON object and **no** Markdown, code-fencing, or scratch-pad remnants.

 7. **Ruleâ€‘7 â€“ Metric-KPI guard (evidenceâ€‘aware, mustâ€‘run)**
    â€¢ Apply this check **only** to **decision/target** metric fields.
    â€¢ A cell is a gap **only** if it lacks any or several elements: **statistic/threshold/unit/window and instrumentation owner**, while there was enough information in clientspecs and dependencies to present each element.
    â€¢ **Metricâ€“type coherence:** flag as a gap when the **statistic type does not match the measure type** (e.g., percentile on Boolean outcomes; `success rate p99`).
    â€¢ If TBD / N/A / Not required/ etc. was used in metric field - that is ok, do not raise a gap, unless TBD / N/A / Not required/ etc. are incorrect.
    â€¢ For **vanity/trend** fields, treat KPI completeness as **advisory**; do not raise unless it contradicts the spec or blocks decisions or not actionable.
    â€¢ Accept equivalent phrasings for windows/units/statistics (e.g., monthly/weekly/rolling 30 d; %, ms; success rate/mean/p95). Do not accept incoherent combinations per previous bullet.
    â€¢ If invalid, fire the KPI-FORMAT trigger (see list) and raise a gap.
    â€¢ Instrumentation owner is mandatory for decision metrics; optional for vanity/trend unless explicitly required by spec.
    â€¢ **Observability/fitness:** reject **unmeasurable or behaviorâ€‘blended** KPIs.
      â€“ Ban objectives like `Zero security breaches in 30 d` (replace with system SLO surrogates).
      â€“ Split user behavior from system reliability (avoid â€œadmin login success rateâ€ as a system KPI).



#Empty cell policy
## Cell can not be completely empty. If column truly does not apply to this row/ column in general, but the spec makes it optional for this row/ spec/dependencies donâ€™t give enough to set a value safely/ a required value is known to be needed but not yet decided  - cell must be populated by creator prompt with N/A/ Not required/ Insufficient data/ TBD.
## Failure to follow this policy by creator prompt is low impact issue.

# Severity guidance
â€¢ Critical â€” Spec/security/legal conflict or blocked core flow; unimplemented CRITICAL/HIGH mandatory fix; Decision metric nonâ€‘actionable on a releaseâ€‘critical path
â€¢ High â€” Major decision quality or coverage risk (e.g., conflicting requirements, broken PK uniqueness, cross-artifact contradiction without Ruleâ€‘1 deferral)
â€¢ Medium â€” Actionable but not releaseâ€‘blocking (e.g., ambiguous values with safe defaults, inconsistent units, incomplete but interpretable Decision metric)
â€¢ Low â€” Stylistic/orthographic/format nits; naming drift; vanity/trend completeness suggestions; acceptable placeholders used correctly
â€¢ **Impact calibration for baselines:** Unknown authâ€‘context + absent baseline â‡’ **Low**; named stateâ€‘changing endpoint without control â‡’ **Medium**; explicit public unauthenticated write without throttling â‡’ **High**
â€¢ **Unknownâ€‘context policy (aligned with qualifiers):** For AOB/CPI, when applicability is unclear **raise Low** `crossâ€‘artifact` and state the uncertainty; **suppress only** with positive evidence of nonâ€‘applicability.

# SCOPE-OF-REVIEW MATRIX (hard guardrails)
# Derive allowed topics from the Current Artifact's column set and the official table catalog.
# If the official table catalog is absent from Dependencies, treat only the ğŸŸ§ Upcoming artifacts in this phase as authoritative for Ruleâ€‘1 deferral.
# If a topic is not owned by the current schema, apply Ruleâ€‘1 and SKIP â€” **except**:
# â€¢ CPI: current artifact must host prerequisite primitives/fields for a capability asserted elsewhere â†’ in scope (anchor to current artifact).
# â€¢ AOB: always in scope unless a precise owner is named downstream in this phase.
# **Crossâ€‘artifact invariants:** Even if owned elsewhere, you **must** raise a gap marked `crossâ€‘artifact` (use an allowed `gapType`, typically `MissedRequirement`) when the current artifact makes an assertion that requires undefined data/primitives elsewhere (see Ruleâ€‘1 exceptions).
# Examples:
# - For 1.1.0 "Input": in-scope = required rows present; column presence; internal consistency;
#   high-level coverage vs ClientSpec. Out-of-scope = metrics, security/control details, test plans,
#   trace links â†’ DEFER to artifacts that own those columns (e.g., 1.1.2 "Domain Context" â†’ "Potential Metrics").
# - For 1.1.2 "Domain Context": "Potential Metrics" cells must be quantitative KPIs (Rule-7).

# DETERMINISTIC DEFERRAL (augment Rule-1)
# Build a topicâ†’column map from the official table catalog **in Dependencies** and the Upcoming artifacts (names + column headers).
# Require an explicit matching **column** in the upcoming artifact to defer.
# If a candidate topic maps to an Upcoming column and will be most likely implemented there, DROP the issue **only if** that artifact can legitimately **own** it (same abstraction level/columnâ€‘set). DROP **unless** it is:
#   â€¢ a capabilityâ€‘prerequisite invariant needed by the current artifact, or
#   â€¢ an ownerless crossâ€‘cutting baseline (security, GDPR evidence, instrumentation).

# EVIDENCE-ANCHOR REQUIREMENT (augment Rule-3)
# Before recording any issue, privately locate:
#  (1) the expected column in Current Artifact; and
#  (2) the strongest matching substring in Current Artifact.
# If (2) exists and is adequate-quality â†’ DO NOT raise the issue.
# **Misâ€‘anchor check:** confirm the chosen locator **owns** the control per the Ownerâ€‘Tier Map; if not, **relocate** or mark `crossâ€‘artifact`; do **not** attach controls to nonâ€‘owning components.
# **Locator audit (required):** Treat misâ€‘anchored findings as falseâ€‘positives. Before emission, reâ€‘check ownerâ€‘tier; if uncertain, **prefer** `crossâ€‘artifact <index> Whole artifact` rather than anchoring to a nonâ€‘owner. Category labels are not owners.
# When a baseline concern is valid but no owner exists in the current artifact, raise `crossâ€‘artifact` and name the target artifact type/owner in the recommendation (do not park the finding on an unrelated row).
# **Ownerless/CPI exception:** for AOB, CPI, and **ghostâ€‘dependencies**, you may use **`<index> Whole artifact`** as the locator; do not defer solely because no specific column exists.
# **Unknownâ€‘context handling:** Raise only when applicability is evidenced; if applicability is unknown, skip and recommend documenting applicability context.
# When locus is outside the current artifact or owner is unclear, include the literal token crossâ€‘artifact in the shortDescription.

# UNIVERSAL REVIEW-TRIGGER CHECKLIST (current-artifact focus â€” **24 triggers**)
**A trigger fires only when the current artifactâ€™s content or explicit dependencies provide concrete evidence matching the triggerâ€™s condition.**
 Use these triggers on *current* artifact:
 â€¢ The Client Specification outranks dependency artifacts (â€œspec-winsâ€).
 â€¢ Do **not** penalise the current artifact for errors that exist **only** upstream unless it copies or relies on them.
 â€¢ If a trigger fires and neither Rule-1 nor Rule-2 forbids it, raise at least one matching gap/excess.

 1  SPEC-ALIGNMENT GAP / CONFLICT
    â€¢ Current content contradicts or omits an explicit requirement in the Client Specification.
    â€¢ Extra detail is welcome **unless it conflicts** with the spec or a non-conflicting dependency, **or changes behavior**; if it does, raise a gap/excess.
    Note: When the spec is silent and a dependency proposes stricter security defaults, prefer the stricter default unless it conflicts with spec or Upcoming artifacts own the decision.
 2  DEPENDENCY MISALIGNMENT  (spec-wins still applies)
    â€¢ Current artifact contradicts a dependency artifact *that does not itself conflict with the specification*.
    â€¢ If the spec is silent and two artifacts differ, treat the earlier one as reference and raise a gap/excess.
    â€¢ **Policy coherence:** contradictory strength levels for the same control across accessible sources (e.g., `recommended` vs `enforced`) â†’ raise a gap and name both sources.
    Note: When the spec is silent and a dependency proposes stricter security defaults, prefer the stricter default unless it conflicts with spec or Upcoming artifacts own the decision.
 3  INTERNAL INCONSISTENCY
    â€¢ Any two rows, columns, or cells inside the artifact conflict.
 4  GRANULARITY / DETAIL MISMATCH
    â€¢ Information is so coarse it blocks implementation **or** so fine it over-specifies beyond the specâ€™s intended scope.
    â€¢ **Endâ€‘toâ€‘end implementability (promise â†” enabling counterparts):** For any declared behavior, constraint, assurance,
      or requirement, the Current Artifact must either (a) specify the concrete mechanism and named owner in its own
      columns/sections, or (b) explicitly reference a dependency that names the mechanism and owner (table/section/column).
      Mechanism/owner pairs must cover the interfacing tiers that make the promise real (UI â†” API â†” service logic â†” data model â†” security/control).
      If neither (a) nor (b) is satisfied, raise a gap.
    â€¢ **Criticalâ€‘path TBD:** primary components/technologies marked `TBD`/`to be selected` â†’ at **phaseâ€‘end**, raise a gap if no binding decision/owner exists.
 5  MISSING VALUE WHILE SOURCE EXISTS
    â€¢ Blank / placeholder although data is present in the spec or a non-conflicting dependency.
    â€¢ If a required cell is blank where the policy demands N/A/TBD, raise Low MissedRequirement.
 6  DUPLICATE / OBSOLETE / EXCESS CONTENT
    â€¢ Redundant row, duplicate ID, obsolete element, or row count exceeds a stated cap (when such a cap is defined).
 7  IDENTIFIER / LINK ERROR & COLUMN-SET INTEGRITY
    â€¢ Malformed, broken, non-unique ID, wrong cross-reference, **or** a mandatory column-set/triplet is only partially filled. (Trace links in 1.1.0â€“1.1.4 exempt per Rule-2.)
    â€¢ Includes foreign keys that point to no existing row in declared dependencies.
    â€¢ **Ghost dependency:** a named dependency (component/service/job/interface) lacks a **defining artifact** in the accessible set â€” i.e., nowhere is it the **primary subject** with responsibilities/interfaces/owner/safeguards. Mentions in â€œDependencies/Relationshipsâ€ do **not** count â†’ raise `crossâ€‘artifact`.
    â€¢ **Postâ€‘1.1.4 ID stability (mandatory):** Same requirement ID must preserve semantics across artifacts; drift â‡’ raise a gap anchored to the current artifact.
 8  TRACE LOOP INCOMPLETE
    â€¢ Entity/requirement appears here but nowhere downstream **after the partner artifactâ€™s planned index has been delivered.**
    â€¢ Do not apply to artifacts 1.1.0â€“1.1.4 due to the traceability waiver.
 9  METRIC / TARGET INCOMPLETENESS OR CONFLICT
    â€¢ Quantitative target lacks unit, threshold, window, population, **instrumentation owner**, or source; non-SI/IEC unit; non-ISO-8601 timestamp; > 4 decimals; or duplicate/conflicting targets exist for the same ID.
    â€¢ **Metricâ€“type coherence:** statistic type incompatible with measure type (e.g., percentile on Boolean success); or window/population mis-specified.
    â€¢ Success > 100 %, negative latency, mutually exclusive limits, etc.; **crossâ€‘source drift**.
10  UNREALISTIC / IMPOSSIBLE VALUES
11  STRATEGY / PROCESS DEVIATION
    â€¢ Violates the agreed methodology, toolchain, or Definition-of-Done for this artifact type.
12  SECURITY / COMPLIANCE GAP
    â€¢ Missing, weak, duplicated, or outdated control; unmet legal/licence/privacy requirement.
    â€¢ **Security baselines (ownerless):** for authenticated stateâ€‘changing requests expect CSRF defenses; rateâ€‘limit/bruteâ€‘force throttles; session cookie HttpOnly/Secure/SameSite; idle and absolute session timeouts; basic output encoding in admin UI. Apply the **session scheme invariant** from AOB.    â€¢ **GDPR evidence:** when consent/notice/erasure is in scope anywhere, expect consent boolean, policy version, timestamp, actor/source, retention/erasure fields, and export/erasure workflow owner.
    â€¢ **Erasure vs softâ€‘delete:** if softâ€‘delete exists and erasure is promised, require hardâ€‘delete path + SLA.
    â€¢ AOB items apply (see Definitions).
13  PERFORMANCE / QUALITY MISALIGNMENT
    â€¢ Latency, throughput, availability, maintainability, or data-quality target mis-aligned with spec or SLA.
    â€¢ **Feasibility realism (mandatory):** challenge HA claims lacking required primitives (e.g., LB, stateless autoscaling, replication, zone failover, RPO/RTO); raise anchored to current artifact and name missing owner.
14  VERSION / TOOLCHAIN MISMATCH
    â€¢ Runtime, library, or pin conflicts with the approved tech stack.
15  LOGGING / AUDIT / DEPRECATION DEFECT
    â€¢ Required log field missing, audit format wrong, deprecation timeline absent.
    â€¢ **Dataâ€‘model prerequisite:** when `RBAC enforced`, `MFA`, `Session management`, `Audit logging`, or `Consent logging` is claimed, require **either** corresponding persistent fields/schemas **or** an explicit external authority + mapping/owner; otherwise raise **CrossArtifactGap** anchored to the current artifact.
16  ACCESSIBILITY / LOCALISATION OMISSION
    â€¢ Required WCAG tag, language fallback, or locale rule missing.
17  BUSINESS CONSTANT / CONFIG ERROR
    â€¢ Wrong, stale, or hard-coded business rule or constant.
    â€¢ **Standards sanity:** unrealistic maxima/minima for widelyâ€‘standardized fields (e.g., email localâ€‘part length cap far below common standards) unless justified by business rule.
18  RISK / ASSUMPTION UNTRACKED
    â€¢ Known risk, assumption, or mitigation from spec/dependencies not mirrored here when it should be.
19  RATE-LIMIT / ERROR-BUDGET / SLA CEILING MISSING
    â€¢ Expected ceilings absent or inconsistent with performance objectives.
20  DECISION / INFO-CRUMB ERROR
    â€¢ Missing, duplicate, or malformed crumb in `metadata.notesFromLLM`, or fired trigger without matching crumb.
21  UNRESOLVED-NOTES VIOLATION
    â€¢ `unresolvedNotes` missing when gaps blocked, present when none blocked, reason > 120 chars, or pattern invalid.
22  PROGRESS-TRACKER LEAKAGE
    â€¢ Progress-Tracker table or sample row still present in artifact.
23  KPI-FORMAT DEFECT
    â€¢ Column header contains `Metric`/`Metrics` but cell is not a quantitative KPI (no statistic, threshold, unit, window, **or owner**), **or** uses incoherent statisticâ€‘type.
24  CUSTOM-INSTR MISMATCH
    â€¢ Current artifact violates or omits a mandatory point in its Artifact-specific custom instructions block.
ğŸ‘‰ **If any trigger fires and neither Ruleâ€‘1 nor Ruleâ€‘2 forbids it, at least one corresponding gap/excess *must* appear in `identifiedIssues`; omission is a *Highâ€‘severity reviewer oversight*.** Returning an empty list when a trigger fired violates the **Zeroâ€‘issues guard**.

# Triggers - gapType mapping:
  â€¢ Triggers 1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,10,11,17,18,20,21,22,24 â†’ MissedRequirement (unless clearly security/compliance).
  â€¢ 12,15 â†’ SecurityGap or ComplianceGap (as applicable).
  â€¢ 13,19 â†’ PerformanceGap.
  â€¢ 16 â†’ UsabilityGap.
  â€¢ 9,23 â†’ MissedRequirement (KPI format) unless a policy mandate makes it ComplianceGap.

# CROSSâ€‘CUTTING BASELINES (for Ruleâ€‘0.1 and Ruleâ€‘5 bias)
# The following expectations are considered ownerless unless an upcoming artifact lists the exact column/section:
# â€¢ Security controls: CSRF for **authenticated** stateâ€‘changing requests; rateâ€‘limit/throttling (for **public/unauthenticated** writes); session cookie flags; session timeouts; basic output encoding for admin UI.
# â€¢ GDPR/Privacy evidence: consent boolean, policy version, timestamp, actor/source; retention/erasure fields; export/erasure workflow owner.
# â€¢ Capability prerequisites: RBAC roles/permissions; MFA secret/method/recovery; audit log schema; metrics instrumentation owner/source.
# â€¢ Deterministic encryption when UNIQUE fields are encrypted at rest **and uniqueness is explicitly required**, or documented lookup/ADR; never infer uniqueness.
# **Privacy scope note:** Apply GDPR evidence only when personal data is in scope; if unclear, **recommend** documenting data categories, sources, and owner (do not raise a gap).

# ENUM LOCK (hard rule â€“ any other token will be rejected):
 1. "impact":      **Critical | High | Medium | Low**   â† exact spelling, title case
 2. "knownIssue":  **NewIssue | KnownIssue | InProgress**   â† no other text, no extra spaces
 3. gapType list (choose the closest domain for each issue; applies to gaps **and** excesses):
 MissedRequirement | SecurityGap | ComplianceGap | PerformanceGap | UsabilityGap | Other.
 *IMPORTANT*: Use only the gapType values shown above; never invent new types! Invented gap types will be rejected!

# Locator rule â€“ every shortDescription **must begin with the current artifact index** (e.g. 1.1.2) **followed by a space**, then:
 â€¢ a row ID (e.g. I-12) **optionally followed by** a column name, OR
 â€¢ a column name alone, OR
 â€¢ *Whole artifact* (when no specific row/column applies).
 â€¢ If the secondary locator is omitted, write `Whole artifact` after the index.
 â€¢ Examples:
   â€¢ `1.1.2 I-12`
   â€¢ `1.1.2 SLA`
   â€¢ `1.1.2 I-12 SLA`
   â€¢ `1.1.2 Whole artifact`
 â€¢ The locator counts toward the word limit.
 â€¢ Use <index> Whole artifact when the issue spans multiple rows/columns; if uncertain, anchor to the broadest specific row/column

# Style rules:
 - shortDescription: telegraphic noun phrase, **max 12 words** incl. artifact-index locator; hyphen-joined terms count as one word.
 - recommendation: **mandatory**; imperative verb, **â‰¤ 10 words**.
  â€¢ Prefer citing the **exact column in the current artifact**.
  â€¢ Crossâ€‘artifact is a literal marker included in shortDescription; it is not a gapType. Use any appropriate gapType (e.g., MissedRequirement, SecurityGap) and include the marker text crossâ€‘artifact in the shortDescription.
  â€¢ For crossâ€‘artifact fixes, **name the ownerâ€‘tier**; only name an artifact index + column when conclusively identifiable. **Do not fabricate indices.**
  â€¢ Reference the same locator when helpful (â€œLink I-07 to US-03â€).
  â€¢ Describe the *next concrete action* (Add / Remove / Link / Rewrite / Defer / Verify â€¦), and include the exact row/column or spec-ID to modify so the artifact-creator can copy the instruction verbatim.
  â€¢ Never leave it blank; write â€œInvestigate root-causeâ€ **only** if no fix is obvious.
   **ğŸš¨ If either field exceeds its word-limit, drop trailing words until limit is met.**
  â€¢ Good vs bad length examples:
    âœ” `1.2.7 All trace links missing` (5 words)
    âœ˜ `1.2.7 Whole artifact Questions for Stakeholders Table trace link missing` (13 words)
 - If a phrase exceeds 12 words, compress or drop adjectives.
 - Do not end either field with a period; remove any generated trailing period.
 - *IMPORTANT*: Prefer backticks for the locator; escaping is a fallback. Inside JSON strings escape any inner double-quotes (" ") or wrap the locator in back-ticks ( `like this` ); un-escaped quotes will be rejected.
 - **Reminder â€“ Traceability waiver:** For artifacts **1.1.0 â†’ 1.1.4**, raise **no traceability gaps of any kind** (Rule-2).
   â€¢ Any attempt to raise such a gap is a direct violation and must be omitted from `identifiedIssues`.
 - Limit â€“ output at most **20 issues** to avoid overflow.
 ğŸ”’ Before returning JSON: if any `gapID` repeats, revise until unique.
  - **FINAL REMINDER** â€“ Before emitting JSON, verify you have **not** raised a gap handled by *Upcoming artifacts in this phase*.
  - **Wordâ€‘count rule:** Count every whitespaceâ€‘separated token toward the 12â€‘word limit **except** the exact token `crossâ€‘artifact`.

# COMPLIANCE CHECKLIST
 â“ª  Compliance Checklist â€“ perform silently before JSON
 (scratch-pad: Rule-1 Rule-2 Rule-3 Rule-4 Rule-5 Rule-6 Rule-7 ShortDescriptionâ‰¤12 Recommendationâ‰¤10 JSON-valid)

# TASKS â€“ run all; omit any that pass. Always obey ABSOLUTE RULES
 0 Preparation
  â€¢ Load Client Specification, dependency artifacts, Current Artifact, and Unresolved Issues.
  â€¢ For each item in *Unresolved Issues*, **must** re-check whether the underlying defect is still present **in this artifact**; if not, do **not** re-raise it.
  â€¢ Mark topics covered by ğŸŸ§ Upcoming artifacts (Rule-1) and the 1.1.0 â€“ 1.1.4 trace-waiver scope (Rule-2).

 1 Evidence scan (Rule-3)
  â€¢ Search CS â†’ Dependencies â†’ Current Artifact (case-insensitive substrings, indirect links).
  â€¢ Apply Rule-3 positive-evidence check before flagging a gap
  â€¢ If the requirement is already met in Current Artifact and is well-specified â†’ stop.

 2 Trigger sweep
  â€¢ Iterate through the 24 Universal Review-Triggers.
  â€¢ For every live trigger not deferred by Rule-1/2, create â‰¥ 1 candidate finding *within the SCOPE-OF-REVIEW MATRIX*.
  â€¢ **Cluster sweep:** If any AOB/CPI item triggers, emit **one aggregated** `crossâ€‘artifact` **cluster finding** that lists the specific missing primitives; **MUST NOT** emit isolated nearâ€‘duplicates; **reuse gapID**.


 3 Classify & draft rows
  â€¢ Choose gapType, impact, and precise locator; craft shortDescription (â‰¤ 12 words) and recommendation (â‰¤ 10 words).
  â€¢ Reject any issue lacking an internal evidence anchor or a column-precise recommendation.
  â€¢ Apply knownIssue logic: reuse gapID (KnownIssue / InProgress) or leave blank (NewIssue).

 4 Deduplicate & consolidate (Rule-4)
  â€¢ Merge duplicate findings under a single gapID; widen or narrow the locator as required by the examples.
  â€¢ Verify every gapID is unique.

 5 Quota & quick-check
  â€¢ If > 20 issues, retain the highest-impact ones first.
  â€¢ Order by severity: **Critical â†’ High â†’ Medium â†’ Low**; prefer ownerless/CPI and **ghostâ€‘dependency** gaps. If > 20, retain the highestâ€‘impact first.
  â€¢ Re-run the Upcoming-Artifact scan; drop any entry that should be silently deferred.

 6 Emit JSON only
  â€¢ Output exactly one object:
   { "questionText": â€¦, "identifiedIssues": [â€¦] }
  â€¢ No extra prose, markdown, or code fencing.
(<end of instruction block>)

(<start of project data block:>)
# PROJECT DATA:
 1. Dependencies (client specification + other artifacts):
  ClientSpec:
I want a simple webpage where people can give feedback about our product or service. People should be able to leave feedback anonymously, but it would be good if they have an option to add their email in case we want to follow up. Each piece of feedback should show when it was submitted. There should be a simple way for me or someone else to log in securely to see all the feedback that has been left. We also need to be able to delete feedback if necessary, but it should ask for confirmation before deleting anything. Itâ€™s important that people's email addresses and the login information for managing the feedback are kept safe and secure. We also need to let people know how their email addresses will be used if they provide them, to keep everything compliant with privacy laws like GDPR. The page should be simple and easy to use, and it should look good and work smoothly on different web browsers like Chrome, Firefox, and Edge.

--- DEPENDENCY: Artifact 1.1.0 (Input) ---
Client specification (summary) | Simple webpage for anonymous feedback, optional email, admin view, delete with confirm, GDPR notice, responsive | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Anonymous feedback | Allow anonymous submissions; store feedback text plus minimal metadata: submission_id, timestamp, ip-hash | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Optional email capture | Optional email field; encrypt at rest, mark contact_intent flag, do not require for submit | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Submission timestamp | Record ISO-8601 UTC timestamp for each submission and surface in admin UI | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Admin authentication | Least-privilege admin roles, strong password + MFA, session rotation with rotatedAt and TTL | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Delete with confirmation | Admin delete requires explicit confirmation UI; record deletion event with actor_id and timestamp | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Data protection for emails and credentials | Encrypt emails and admin credentials at rest; TLS for transport; role-based access and audit logs | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Privacy / GDPR notice | Show brief notice when email requested covering usage, retention and opt-out; link to full policy | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Responsive cross-browser UI | Accessible UI, keyboard navigable, responsive across desktop and mobile widths | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Initial user scenario: submit feedback | Anon user opens page, enters feedback, optionally adds email, submits, sees confirmation receipt | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Initial user scenario: admin review | Admin logs in, views list sorted by timestamp, filters, inspects feedback, may delete with confirm | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Success metric: submission reliability | Submission success rate >= 99.0 % over PT30D for production submissions; source: API-Service logs | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Success metric: UI performance | Median first-contentful-paint <= 2.0 s over PT30D measured in production RUM | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Identifier strategy | Use time-sortable UUID identifiers (time-ordered UUIDs) for feedback and admin actions | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Security baseline | Session cookie flags Secure/HttpOnly/SameSite, idle timeout PT30M, MFA for admin, retention P365D, audit logs | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Rate-limit for submissions | POST /feedback rate-limit 10 requests per IP per PT1M with exponential backoff; instrumented metric owner=SRE | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Session rotation policy | Issue session tokens with rotatedAt timestamp and TTL PT8H; renew on privileged action | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
CSRF and anti-forgery | Admin flows require anti-CSRF token or SameSite=Strict for admin cookies; validate server-side | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Minimal DevSecOps checklist | Enforce TLS, secret rotation, dependency vuln scan, audit logging, least-privilege IAM entries | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
Instrumentation owner for rate-limit metric | Owner: SRE team; metric source: API-Service request counters and throttles; alert on >1% throttle PT1H | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]
--- DEPENDENCY: Artifact 1.1.1 (Main Scenario Table with N modules) ---
M-1 | Public Feedback Form | Open feedback page (responsive, accessible) | Enter feedback text | Optional email field + contact_intent checkbox | Show GDPR/privacy notice and consent checkbox | Submit feedback with ISO-8601 UTC timestamp | FR-005 | POST /feedback rate-limit 10 req per IP per PT1M; metric owner=SRE; source=API-Service counters; 429+exp backoff; TLS; input validation; log throttle events
M-2 | Submission Processing | Validate feedback payload server-side | Sanitize content for display | Mark contact_intent if email present; hash email before persist | Enqueue for storage and notify admin UI | Return success/failure to client with id | FR-022 | Server-side validation; XSS sanitization; hash email before persist; audit write on submit; retry idempotency for ingest
M-3 | Storage | Store feedback records in SQL RDBMS | Encrypt sensitive fields at rest (email, ip-hash) | Enforce least-privilege DB access | Backup cadence PT24H | Retention policy P365D enforcement and secure deletion | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO] | Field-level encryption at rest; TLS in transit; DB access via least-privilege roles; access logs for reads/writes; retention enforcement job
M-4 | Admin UI | Admin login screen (responsive) | List feedback sorted by timestamp | Inspect feedback details | Delete feedback with confirm dialog | Log deletion actor ID and ISO-8601 timestamp | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO] | RBAC for UI actions; CSRF tokens or SameSite=Strict cookies for admin flows; audit trail for deletes; session idle timeout PT30M
M-5 | Admin Authentication | Authenticate admins via OIDC IdP capability | Enforce session cookie flags Secure/HttpOnly/SameSite | Enforce MFA for admin accounts | Rotate sessions on privileged actions and record rotatedAt | Session TTL PT8H; renew on privileged action | FR-025 | OIDC IdP capability; session TTL PT8H; rotatedAt timestamp; idle timeout PT30M; MFA enforcement; secrets rotation policy
M-6 | Privacy & GDPR | Display email-use notice when email requested | Capture consent and contact-intent flags | Provide data access and deletion request process | Support verified data deletion and record event | Surface retention disclosure to admins | [PLACEHOLDER-AUTO] | Record consent and processing purpose in audit logs; encrypt email at rest; deletion audit event with actor_id and timestamp; retention disclosure

 6. Artifact-specific custom instructions
  Use modules and actions from table 1.1.1 Main Scenario Table with N modules. Actions from that table become Components here. Make sure all Actions are included as components. Assign Requirement ID to each Component  
For each component assign Requirement ID, map to a security control and owner, populate Related Reqs, and link potential metrics and V&V focus to those controls

  1) Verify that the artefact is internally consistent, unambiguous, and complete for this development stage. 2) Check that every row traces to the client specification and dependencies. 3) Confirm that any missing content is correctly deferred according to ABSOLUTE RULE 1.

            Illustrative JSON examples (do **not** include in output):

            Example NewIssue (deficiency):
            {
              "gapType": "MissedRequirement",

              "gapID": "",

              "impact": "High",

            }

            Example KnownIssue (excess):
            {
              "gapType": "SecurityGap",

          **JSON-SAFETY RULE â€” Inside every JSON string use ONLY UTF-8 characters that are neither a raw double-quote ( " ) nor an unescaped back-slash ( \ ).
          If you need quotes around a word, wrap them in back-ticks (`like this`) or escape them as "like this".  Use \n only where a newline is required; escape â‰¥ and % inside strings.**

            Return **ONLY** valid JSON:
            {
              "questionText": "{q_text}",
              "identifiedIssues": [
                {
                  "gapType": "...",
                  "shortDescription": "...",
                  "gapID": "some ID (blank if new)",
                  "knownIssue": "KnownIssue | InProgress | NewIssue",
                  "impact": "Critical | High | Medium | Low",
                  "recommendation": "specific recommendation text: locator/action/link"
                }
              ]
            }

# knownIssue flagging:
 â€¢ **Decision block:** If gapID appears in *Unresolved*: if fully fixed â†’ **omit**; if partially fixed â†’ **InProgress**; else **KnownIssue**. If new â†’ **NewIssue**.
 â€¢ Allowed tokens are **exactly** `KnownIssue`, `InProgress`, `NewIssue` (any other value will be rejected).
 â€¢ Always scan the current artifact for partial fixes first; if any are visible, use InProgress with the updated locator.
 â€¢ Use **KnownIssue** when the gapID is still present with **no visible remediation**; if fully remediated in this artifact, **omit** the issue (resolved by omission).
 â€¢ Use **InProgress** only when you explicitly detect partial fixes in this artifact and cite the locator that shows the fix.
 â€¢ Otherwise use **NewIssue**.
 â€¢ **If the gapID you output already appears in *Unresolved Issues* and the problem is still unsolved and is applicable to current artifact fully, you MUST reuse that gapID and set `"knownIssue": "KnownIssue"` (unless you are explicitly marking partial remediation with `"InProgress"`, or the issue is fully `"Resolved"`).  Never label such an issue `"NewIssue"`.**
 â€¢ Any other token in either `gapType` or `knownIssue` will cause the response to be rejected.
 â€¢ If no issues, output { "questionText": "{q_text}", "identifiedIssues": [] }
 â€¢ **Reuse guard:** Before marking `KnownIssue`, reâ€‘check the Current Artifact. If any remediation is visible, **reuse the same `gapID`** but set `"knownIssue": "InProgress"` and update the locator. **Do not** use `KnownIssue` when partial fixes exist.

# QUICK-CHECK STEP â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

  â€¢ If a candidate issueâ€™s primary topic matches an ğŸŸ§ Upcoming artifact â†’ apply Ruleâ€‘1 (skip) **unless**:
    â€“ **AOB** item, or
    â€“ **CPI** needed by the current artifact.
  â€¢ If `shortDescription` contains a substring that equals any Upcoming artifact name â‡’ DEFERRED
  â€¢ Otherwise continue with normal gap evaluation.
  â€¢ Do NOT include the Compliance Checklist in the JSON output
  â€¢ ğŸš« Rule-2 reminder: artifacts 1.1.0-1.1.4 â‡’ traceability gaps are out-of-scope.
  â€¢ Do **not** claim a metric is violated unless the artifact contains measured data; target rows alone are not evidence of failure.
  â€¢ Apply the **ID stability** and **capabilityâ€‘prerequisite** checks before deferral.
  â€¢ Minimise false-positives and false-negatives â€” raise only evidence-backed issues.
  â€¢ Priority: FPâ€‘averse default **except** AOB/CPI/ghostâ€‘dependency/phaseâ€‘end, where **one Low** `crossâ€‘artifact` cluster beats silence when unsure.
  â€¢ Apply the **Zeroâ€‘issues guard (safe)**: use **only** when a trigger has positive applicability evidence, no inâ€‘artifact semantic match exists, and Ruleâ€‘1/2 do not defer; emit **one** Low `crossâ€‘artifact` cluster summary.
  â€¢ Apply the **ID stability** and **capabilityâ€‘prerequisite** checks before deferral.
  â€¢ **Phaseâ€‘end invariants sweep:** on last miniâ€‘iteration or when no upcoming artifacts remain in phase, reâ€‘scan alreadyâ€‘reviewed artifacts in this phase; if any CPI/AOB/**ghostâ€‘dependencies** or criticalâ€‘path `TBD` remain, raise now in the **current artifact** as `crossâ€‘artifact`; do **not** defer.

# **FINAL REMINDER** â€“ Before emitting JSON, verify you have **not** raised a gap handled by *Upcoming artifacts in this phase* and that every `gapID`, enum token, and word-count passes the compliance checklist.

    STEP 1 â€“ Normalise
    â€¢ For *every* issue (known & candidate) create a temporary field called **coreProblem** by:
      â€“ Removing any leading numbering denoting artifact indexes, such as â€œ1.1.4.2 â€ or â€œ1.1.1 â€ or "2.3.1".
      â€“ Lower-casing.

      â€“ Split `shortDescription` at â€œ||â€; treat each part as an alias and normalise separately.
      â€“ If a **row OR column token** (e.g., â€œRow M-06â€, â€œFR-12â€, â€œFB-02â€, â€œSLA columnâ€) is present, **prepend it to coreProblem** so that different rows/columns are not merged.
      â€“ Treat obvious synonyms, abbreviations, and word-form variants as equivalent (e.g., â€œp95â€ â‰ˆ â€œ95th percentileâ€; â€œencryptâ€, â€œencryptionâ€, â€œencryptedâ€).  Do not invent far-fetched matches: use only clear, context-relevant synonyms.

      â€¢ Does the candidate contain a **row/column token**?

            â–¸ If an existing coreProblem **with the same token** matches â†’ duplicate (row â†’ row).

DEBUG (LLMClient): Calling OpenAI with prompt:
 
        You are an expert software engineer and SQA.
        We are currently at iteration (macro=2, phase=FeasibilityStudy, mini=2).

        Your job is to follow these rules and the downgrade guardrail, analyze updated artifact text against artifact-specific issues from a previous iteration, and for each **of those issues** decide on **its** status and in the end output valid JSON.

        Follow these rules:
        For each issue, assign a **newStatus** using the stricter rules below.
          - "Resolved"    â€“ the artifact *demonstrably* satisfies the gapâ€™s acceptance-criterion **and** supplies supporting evidence (e.g., test result that meets the stated target, explicit trace-link, measured KPI â‰¥ goal).
          - "InProgress"  â€“ the artifact introduces a *specific remedial element* (e.g., placeholder trace tag, draft test script, WIP pull-request) **but lacks final evidence**. Merely restating the issue short description/recommendation in artifact text does **not** qualify.
          - "KnownIssue"  â€“ no relevant change toward closing the gap is present.

        Downgrade guardrail â€“ treat the issueâ€™s incoming â€œknownIssueâ€ field as its previous status. You may maintain or upgrade a status (KnownIssue â†’ InProgress â†’ Resolved). **Never downgrade** unless the artifact explicitly removes earlier evidence; if you do, explain why in `notes` (â‰¤ 20 words).

        â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ EDGE-CASE POLICY â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

# ANTIâ€‘OVERSPECIFICATION & ANTIâ€‘LOCKâ€‘IN (global)
 â€¢ Default to capabilityâ€‘based nouns (e.g., â€œOIDC IdPâ€, â€œS3â€‘compatible object storageâ€, â€œSQL RDBMSâ€).
 â€¢ Do not name vendors, paid SKUs, or singleâ€‘cloud managed services before an ADR explicitly approves them,
   unless they appear in original client specifications (as the only option) or in a Critical/High bullet.
 â€¢ Prefer portable standards (e.g., OIDC, OAuth 2.1, OpenMetrics, S3 API, SQL RDBMS) when a choice is needed.
 â€¢ If Sample data rows mention vendors, treat them as examples; replace with capability nouns.
 â€¢ Overspecification = naming a vendor/product/nonâ€‘portable API where the spec doesnâ€™t require it and a
   standardsâ€‘based capability noun exists.
 â€¢ Vendor names and techâ€‘locks are allowed only when the client specification explicitly mandates a single vendor/technology (not merely as an example).  â€¢ Decision timing: postpone tool/vendor picks to backlog phase (current phase is FeasibilityStudy).

# #Cell fill policy
Never leave a cell blank. If a column truly does not apply to this row or you cannot safely supply a concrete value, write exactly one of these tokens (case sensitive):
â€¢	N/A â€” column truly does not apply to this row
â€¢	Not required â€” column is applicable in general, but the spec makes it optional for this row
â€¢	Insufficient data â€” spec/dependencies donâ€™t give enough to set a value safely
â€¢	TBD â€” a required value is known to be needed but not yet decided
Semantics:
N/A = not relevant â€¢ Not required = optional here â€¢ Insufficient data = unknown due to missing inputs â€¢ TBD = known required, undecided

## **MANDATORY-FIX RULE**
*If the {highlighted_msg} block contains any **CRITICAL** or **HIGH**-severity bullets* you **must** for **each** bullet:
1. **Implement** the recommended action **or** leave it unresolved **only** when blocked, in which case add a key-value entry under `metadata.unresolvedNotes` exactly as specified in Step B.
2. Record the bullet in the **Progress Tracker** with the same `GapID` and mark status **Resolved**, **Partially**, or **Unresolved** as appropriate.
 (This rule has equal precedence with â€œSpec-winsâ€; obey both even if they conflict with other guidance.) Update row content, donâ€™t add commentary
 â€¢ If a CRITICAL/HIGH bullet clearly belongs to **another artifact**, do **not** duplicate that content here.  Instead, leave the gap *Unresolved* and add an entry under `metadata.unresolvedNotes` using the **cross-artifact scope** reason pattern described in Step B.
 â€¢ If a CRITICAL/HIGH fix conflicts with the client spec:
    â€“ Do **not** implement the fix.
    â€“ Log the gap in `metadata.unresolvedNotes` with reason "spec conflict".

## âš™ï¸ DECISION-&-INFO-CRUMB RULE (global)
*INTERNAL â€” never emit the scratch-pad*

When you must invent **any numeric threshold, enumerated option or tooling/architecture choice**:
 1. Draft â‰¥ 2 candidate rows with **Perf / Cost / Maintainability / Security** scores 1-5.
 2. Pick the winner (highest Total  â†’  highest Security  â†’  lowest Cost).
 3. DO NOT print the draft table.
 4. Fill the official artifact only with the winning figure/option.
 5. **Also** detect passive facts that (a) alter behaviour of â‰¥ 1 earlier artifact in the next macro/phase **and** (b) are absent from the upstream spec blocks â€” see the 13-item trigger list below.
 6. For every decision *or* info-trigger, append **1-5 crumbs** in `metadata.notesFromLLM`, separated by `" | "`.
  â€¢ Format: `# DEC-<nn>: <WHAT> â€” <WHY>`  (no trailing pipes)
  â€¢ `<WHAT>`  = reusable noun phrase **â‰¤ 6 words** (*do **not** add artifact IDs*).
  â€¢ `<WHY>`   = one short motive (â‰¤ 8 words) starting with a verb.
  â€¢ Max 65 characters per crumb.
  â€¢ Use exactly one em-dash (â€”); no trailing pipes.
  â€¢ Number <nn> chronologically per artifact (01, 02 â€¦); restart at each call.
  â€¢ **Uniqueness guard**: emit a crumb **only once per iteration** â€” if an identical `<WHAT>` already exists in dependencies **or previous artifact version**, **skip it and do not increment the counter**.
  â€¢ Always include at least one crumb; if none qualify use `# DEC-00: no cross-artifact impact â€” FYI`.
  â€¢ Example: `# DEC-01: REST/JSON chosen â€” simpler firewall | # DEC-02: UUIDv7 identifiers â€” sortable, time-based`
  â€¢ The **last crumb must not end with `|`**.

## INFO-CRUMB TRIGGERS (emit when any row causes one):
  1 Contract shape changed   2 Schema-migration pattern   3 Trace header/ID
  4 Identifier strategy      5 Crypto/Compliance rule     6 Perf envelope
  7 Ordering/Idempotency     8 Tool/runtime pin           9 Deprecation clock
 10 Business constant        11 Data-quality rule        12 Shard/Partition key
 13 Log/Audit format
### INFO-CRUMB REMINDER
 â€¢ Always emit â‰¥ 1 and â‰¤ 5 crumbs.
 â€¢ Never duplicate an existing crumb from another artifact in the same macro-iteration.
 â€¢ Missing crumb for a fired trigger â‡’ High-severity gap.

##âš ï¸  **Quality Gate Notice**
 â€¢ After you submit your JSON, a *senior reviewer LLM* will score it with the rubric below.
 â€¢ If your score is < 7 / 10, you will be asked to redo the artifact.
 â€¢ Therefore, meet every rubric point **on the first try**.

### EVALUATION RUBRIC *(do **not** output this rubric)*
 â€¢ 10 / 10  All Critical + High CLOSED **in scope**  + â‰¥ 80 % of Med/Low CLOSED **in scope**
 â€¢  7 / 10  All Critical CLOSED, some High remain
 â€¢ â‰¤ 4 / 10  Any Critical issue still open or re-introduced
(The grader is strict and reward-based; aim for 10/10.)


## PROGRESS TRACKER (fill before Step A & update before JSON)
| GapID | Status (Resolved/Partially/Unresolved) | One-line Fix |
|-------|----------------------------------------|--------------|
Fill the table above **before you start step A** and update it again just before sending the JSON.
**Internal use only â€“ never include the table in your final answer.**
(Example row â€“ delete the whole table before sending JSON):
| 7f3942 | Resolved | Add timestamp |
(Delete the entire table before sending your JSON â”€ do **not** leave any sample row.)
**Tracker enforcement â€” complete it only when CRITICAL/HIGH bullets exist. Remove the whole table before emitting JSON.**


# EXECUTION STEPS  (follow A â†’ I)
 A  **Analyse & Align**
   1. Clarify purpose & audience â€“ note the tableâ€™s intent in your private scratch-pad.
   2. Collect source knowledge â€“ pull specs, dependencies, prior artifacts, data samples; discard off-scope info.
   3. Model the domain â€“ list entities â†’ attributes and choose correct row granularity.
   4. Design column set & primary key â€“ one unique fact per column; PK minimal and stable.
   5. Apply **Spec-wins** (treat â€œoptionalâ€ spec bullets as *must* but mark them *(optional)* in rows).
 B  Resolve all unresolved issues listed above **(any severity)** including every CRITICAL/HIGH bullet per the MANDATORY-FIX RULE (skip if â€œNoneâ€); aim for a 10/10 rubric score and update the Progress Tracker.
   â€¢ **ONLY** if a gap is truly blocked, leave it *Unresolved* and add an entry in `metadata.unresolvedNotes` using: `"<gapID>": "<â‰¤120-char reason this gap cannot be fixed right now>"`
   â€¢ If gap is not applicable to current artifact or false (reviewer mistake), consider it blocked and do not resolve it.
   â€¢ Do **not** include the `GapID=` prefix.
   â€¢ List **only** gaps that are still blocked. If none are blocked, omit the `unresolvedNotes` key entirely.
     Acceptable reason patterns (choose **one** per gap; list not exhaustive):
       â€“ conflicting instructions inside this prompt (e.g. spec A demands anonymity; spec B demands user IDs)
       â€“ spec / dependency gap (e.g. encryption algorithm or success metric not supplied)
       â€“ upstream artifact not generated yet in this macro/phase (e.g. dependency table still missing)
       â€“ cross-artifact scope (bullet targets a different artifact that this update cannot fix)
   â€¢ **If a mandatory foreign-key value cannot be resolved from declared dependencies,** omit the entire row **and** add  `"<row-locator>": "missing FK <column> â€“ upstream row absent"` to `metadata.unresolvedNotes`.
 C  Prevent re-opening globally resolved issues (skip if â€œNoneâ€).
 D  Apply relevant lessons learned (**owned by this artifact**; skip if â€œNoneâ€, not applicable, or false).
 E  Sync with updated dependencies (respecting the Spec-wins rule; skip if â€œNoneâ€).
 F  **Deduplicate & Normalise**
   â€¢ Merge or remove duplicate / obsolete rows; keep primary-key uniqueness.
   â€¢ Normalise names & units â€“ apply canonical vocab **consistent with previous version of artifact, dependencies, client specifications**, SI/IEC units, tidy enums, merge synonyms.
   â€¢ Run internal checks â€“ PK uniqueness, no blank mandatory cells, logical bounds (start â‰¤ end, % â‰¤ 100).
 G  **Requirement Coverage & Gap-Filling**
   Ensure every â€œmust / shall / at leastâ€ requirement maps to one row or column; add **only** what is missing. **Do not add rows solely as examples.**
   â€¢ If a spec bullet uses *should / may / could / optional*, add a row **only when this artifact is the natural owner** of that item (e.g. UI spec â†’ UI table).
     â€“ If the requirement clearly belongs to another artifact, skip it here and rely on that artifact to cover it.
     â€“ If you add the row but lack concrete figures, run the **DECISION-SCRATCHPAD** to select a sensible default. Use `[PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]` only when no safe, non-speculative default exists.
   â€¢ When the spec mandates a capability yet omits **specific values or choices** (e.g. â€œhost on a free providerâ€, â€œprovide licence attributionâ€):
       1. First attempt to decide a reasonable industry default via the scratch-pad (e.g. Vercel Free, MIT-style licence-attribution workflow).
       2. If even the scratch-pad cannot yield a defensible choice, add the row with `[PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]` *and* an inline comment explaining why a placeholder was unavoidable.
   â€¢ If you later decide on a value, replace every `[PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]` cell in that row with the chosen value.
   â€¢ For every row that contains a **â€œRelated Reqsâ€, â€œTraceâ€, â€œReq IDâ€** or similar column, populate that cell with **only** a Requirement-ID (`FR-`, `NFR-`, `US-`, etc.).
     â€“ If no suitable ID exists after diligent search, insert `[PLACEHOLDER-AUTO]` and comment â€œawaiting upstream requirementâ€.
H  Sort rows ascending by the primary-key column/columns unless *Special instructions* say otherwise.
I  **Quality-assure & Output**
   1. Quality-assure & iterate â€“ run the Quick Self-Check; confirm no banned meta words, row count â‰¤ 200, etc.
   2. Output the JSON schema shown below.

# STYLE & SIZE RULES
  â€¢ Telegraphic style â€” imperative or noun phrases; each **text** field â‰¤ 120 chars incl. spaces. (If Special instructions demand prose, this overrides the limit **only** for the named columns.)
  â€¢ Do **not** reuse sample nouns/IDs unless they also appear in the client specification.
  â€¢ Ignore any sample columns not present in the column list.
  â€¢ Maximum rows: **200**.
  â€¢ "notesFromLLM" (metadata) is **required**; 1-5 crumbs, total â‰¤ 200 chars (**reviewer enforces**).
  â€¢ No full sentences unless Special instructions require them.
  â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Domain-only rule** â€“ Every **row cell** must describe an *observable product/property* (UI element, API call, metric, control, etc.).
     âœ— Never include in table metaâ€‘process wording such as â€œapply lessonsâ€, â€œupdate dependenciesâ€, â€œresolve issueâ€, â€œprevent reâ€‘emergenceâ€, â€œalign with specâ€, â€œchecklist:â€, etc..
     âœ— Never copy or paraphrase text from MANDATORY-FIX bullets.
     âœ“ Close a gap by **editing the concrete domain data**, not by narrating the fix.
  â€¢ This rule also applies to *any* columns: describe what the **system** does, not what *you, the engineer* will do.
  â€¢ If you add a â€œ# chosen:â€¦ â€ breadcrumb, place it **only** in metadata.notesFromLLM (never as free-text after or before JSON).
  â€¢ If any trigger (see INFOâ€‘CRUMB list) fired, verify the matching crumb is present in `metadata.notesFromLLM` **after composing rows**.
  â€¢ Use strict SI (kB, ms, C) and IEC binary prefixes (KiB, MiB) for sizes; never imperial.
  â€¢ Timestamps: ISO-8601 UTC (`YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ`). Durations: ISO-8601 (`PT3H15M`, `P7D`).
  â€¢ Numbers: period as decimal separator, no thousands separator; â‰¤ 4 decimal places unless higher precision is required.
  â€¢ Safe ASCII symbols only.
  â€¢ **Rowâ€‘type invariant** - All rows must represent the **same entity type** for this artifact; keep it consistent across every row.
(<end of instruction block>)
